title: 113_hr2230
content: The "Track It to Prevent It Act" is the short title of this legislation, with a table of contents outlining the sections of the Act. The "Track It to Prevent It Act" includes sections on findings, definitions, improved climate assessments, inclusion of disciplinary actions, service-wide assessments, health welfare inspections, security reviews, diversity management in sexual harassment cases, and authorization of appropriations. The "Track It to Prevent It Act" includes a section on findings. Congress finds that in fiscal year 2012, there were 3,374 reported sexual assault cases in the Armed Forces, a 6% increase from the previous year. Additionally, approximately 26,000 members made anonymous reports of sexual assault, a significant rise from the previous year. In fiscal year 2012, 6.1% of female Armed Forces members experienced unwanted sexual contact, with 77% reporting such incidents. In fiscal year 2012, 62% of members who experienced unwanted sexual contact also faced some form of retaliation. Commanders are required by law to conduct climate assessments to ensure a safe environment for their units. In fiscal year 2012, 62% of members who experienced unwanted sexual contact also faced retaliation. Commanders must create a safe environment for the unit by identifying trends in bad behavior like sexual harassment and assault through improved assessments and reporting. Members often don't report incidents due to lack of belief in action being taken. Commanders must address sexual misconduct to change military culture and create a safe environment for reporting incidents without fear of career repercussions. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "sexual harassment" is defined in Department of Defense Directive 1350.2, and "sexual assault" refers to offenses described in section 920 of title 10, United States Code. The Secretary of Defense must ensure that command climate assessment results are shared with relevant commanders and higher levels of command. Each military department's Secretary must include a designated form in performance evaluations for senior commanders to indicate if required climate assessments have been conducted. Failure to conduct assessments will have consequences. The Inspector General of the Department of Defense will develop a tracking system to monitor commanders' compliance with conducting command climate assessments. Unit commanders will work with the Inspector General to gather assessments and create compliance reports. Failure to conduct assessments will be noted in a commander's performance evaluation and may impact future promotions. The Inspector General of the Department of Defense will develop a tracking system to monitor commanders' compliance with conducting command climate assessments. Unit commanders will work with the Inspector General to gather assessments and create compliance reports, including an overview of concerns, data on leadership perception, and a strategic plan to address concerns. Failure to conduct assessments may impact future promotions. SEC. 5. INCLUSION OF LETTER OF REPRIMANDS, NONPUNITIVE LETTER OF REPRIMANDS AND COUNSELING STATEMENTS. The Secretary of Defense mandates commanders to include disciplinary actions related to sexual harassment or assault in the performance evaluations of Armed Forces members to increase visibility, identify trends of misconduct early, discipline repeat offenders, and prevent the transfer of sexual offenders. Additionally, there is a provision for service-wide 360 assessments. The Secretary of each military department is required to develop a 360-degree assessment program based on the Army's MSAF Program. The Secretary of Defense must report to Congress on the feasibility of including this approach in performance evaluations. Individual counseling is also mandated as part of the program. Individual counseling is mandated as part of the performance evaluation process in the department. The Secretary of each military department conducts monthly health welfare inspections to ensure security, military readiness, and discipline. Results are shared with commanders. Additionally, there is a review of the security of military installations, including barracks and multi-family residences. The Secretary of Defense will review security measures on military installations, focusing on barracks and multi-family residences to ensure the safety of Armed Forces members and their dependents. This includes identifying security gaps and evaluating the use of 24-hour electronic monitoring or security personnel. The Secretary of Defense will review security measures on military installations, focusing on barracks and multi-family residences to ensure safety. A report with cost estimates to address security gaps and provide 24-hour monitoring will be submitted to Congress within 90 days. The Secretary of Defense will review security measures on military installations, focusing on barracks and multi-family residences to ensure safety. A report with cost estimates to address security gaps and provide 24-hour monitoring will be submitted to Congress within 90 days. Additionally, there will be a review of the Office of Diversity Management and Equal Opportunity role in sexual harassment cases. The Secretary of Defense will conduct a review of the Office of Diversity Management and Equal Opportunity to identify resource gaps, evaluate its role in sexual harassment cases, and assess its collaboration with the Sexual Assault Prevention and Response Office. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal year 2014 to carry out the Act.
